title: Newquay to Crantock Walk Route

nearby.description: Perranporth to Holywell Bay Coastal Walk

images.title: Tony Atkin / Walking on Towan Head
images.caption: Walking on Towan Head. Looking out to sea from the footpath around this headland.

images.title: Kate Jewell / Fistral Beach from Towan Head
images.caption: Fistral Beach from Towan Head. A mecca for surfers. Reputedly the best surfing beach in Cornwall.

images.title: Frances Watts / Pentire Point West, looking to Pentire Point East
images.caption: Pentire Point West, looking to Pentire Point East. The National Trust farms these meadows in a way that encourages arable 'weeds' such as these poppies and corn marigolds, at their best in early July. A kind of Cornish machair.

images.title: Philip Halling / Trig point on Pentire Point
images.caption: Trig point on Pentire Point. This trig point (No. S7923) near Pentire Point is 83m above sea level and just inland from the coastal path. The north Cornish coast stretches in the background to Tintagel and beyond.

images.title: Tony Atkin / Crantock Beach
images.caption: Crantock Beach. At the mouth of the River Gannel

images.title: Tony Atkin / Crantock Village
images.caption: Crantock Village. Taken at a road junction on the western edge of the village.

description: This circular walk takes you from Newquay to Crantock via Towan Head and Pentire Point. The walk starts from the town centre next to the train station and bus station. From here you can pick up the South West Coast Path and follow the waymarked trail up to Towan Head. You then head south along the popular surfing area at Fistral Beach before coming to Pentire. Follow the footpath around the headland at Pentire Point where there are nice views down to the lovely Crantock Beach. After passing around Pentire Point you can catch the Fernpit Ferry over the River Gannel to the Crantock side. During high tide in the summer season, the Boathouse provides access between Crantock Beach and East Pentire headland, Newquay. At low tide a foot bridge will allow you to walk across the river free of charge.  On the other side follow the path along the Rushy Green before heading south east into Crantock village. The coast path then runs south east to Trevemper before crossing the Gannel and returning to Newquay.
